36.text: Welcome to the library of the Royal College of Physicians for this

39.text: year's Richard Dimbleby lecture. Tonight it asks a question that all

47.text: of us must now face, how to die well, as we come to terms with an

50.text: increasingly ageing population, many of whom will be suffering from

54.text: long-term, incurable illness, it's become an issue that can't be ignored.

58.text: This year we have with us for this lecture, Sir Terry Pratchett,

63.text: the first novelist to give the Richard Dimbleby lecture,

67.text: a hugely successful writer, who to the envy of many other writers, has

73.text: sold over 65 million books, which have been translated into 37 languages.

77.text: He received a knighthood in 2009 for his services to literature.

81.text: Perhaps his greatest accolade is when the BBC had a poll

85.text: asking the British public to name their favourite novel, there were

90.text: only two writers who had five books in the top 100.

93.text: One was Charles Dickens and the other, yes, was Terry Pratchett.

106.text: In tonight's lecture, which is called Shaking Hands With Death,

111.text: Sir Terry will give his account of why he believes we should be

115.text: allowed to choose how and when we end our lives. He refers to the

121.text: this as assisted death. For him it's not an academic debate.

127.text: In 2007 he was diagnosed with a very rare form of early onset

131.text: Alzheimer's disease. At the time he boldly declared Alzheimer's would

142.text: be sorry that it got him. He fought back by donating $1 million to fund

147.text: research into dementia. I must explain one thing, tonight he has

150.text: an understudy here, one of the side effects of his type of Alzheimer's

155.text: is that Sir Terry can find it difficult to read, a struggle to read.

160.text: So at his own request, he has what he describes as a stunt

168.text: Who is going to read the speech on his behalf. He suggested his great

175.text: friend and colleague, the actor, Tony Robinson, forever Baldrick to

180.text: you and me, who has made his own compelling documentary on dementia

184.text: and is an ambassador for the Alzheimer's Society. Tony Robinson

190.text: will read the body of the speech. First, to give his introduction to

194.text: his Richard Dimbleby lecture, please welcome Sir Terry Pratchett.

218.text: Thank you very much, David. Thank you all. Firstly I must express my

222.text: gratitude and grateful thanks to the Dimbleby family for asking me

228.text: to give this lecture today. I Cherish what I suspect was their

234.text: reason or at least part of their reason for inviting me. When I was

241.text: a very young newspaper journalist, learning my trade, we used to

250.text: report in our newspaper that people had died of "a long illness ".

258.text: Everybody knew what it meant. But no-one spoke its name outloud. Then,

265.text: when Richard Dimbleby died of cancer in 1965, his family said

272.text: that he had, in fact, died of cancer. And this shocked the nation

276.text: that a Dimbleby was mortal and that they had actually used the

282.text: forbidden word. Somehow I felt that was a marvellous thing, because it

287.text: seemed to me that the war on cancer developed momentum right at that

293.text: time. Before you can kill the monster, I always say, you have to

300.text: be prepared to say its name. It was an echo of that distant example

303.text: that prompted me to stand up two years ago and announce that I had a

309.text: form of Alzheimer's disease. Alzheimer's has been hidden in

315.text: darkness and the Dimbleby family's decision to be open about Richard's

320.text: death were at the soul and centre of my own decision. I wanted there

326.text: to be the -- determination and a reckoning. My name is Terry

332.text: Pratchett. I'm sure you know by now, I've heard myself called Mr

337.text: Alzheimer's. What they're going to be calling me in the morning,

357.text: I've strifb hard to make the world aware of it. (striven) and what is

361.text: taking place to bring the monster down. Then I realised there was

371.text: another taboo. I'm going to talk today about death. But first I have

379.text: a pleasurable little chore. I may be Mr Alzheimer's, I may the -- be

383.text: the one that gets in the newspapers. But there are about half a dozen

388.text: people here who are ambassadors for the Alzheimer's Society and who

393.text: have various forms of the disease and they go around the country.

397.text: They talk to people and explain to them about it. As it were, they act

401.text: as a human face, because it's when you meet the people that have got

407.text: it and talk to them, that you start to understand. I suppose I get what

412.text: might be the kudos, but they do a lot of the work. So gentlemen,

432.text: ladies, I thank you very much. I would dearly love to have read

438.text: this allowed -- aloud, but I know that my friend will do it almost as

446.text: And so it is with great pleasure and a certain humble feeling, not

475.text: too humble, I must pass you over to When I was a young boy playing on

479.text: the floor of my grandmother's front room, I glanced up at the

483.text: television and saw death talking to a knight. I didn't know very much

487.text: about death at that point. It was the thing that happened to

491.text: budgerigars and hamsters. But it was death with a scythe and an

498.text: amiable manner. I didn't know it at the time, but I just watched a clip

502.text: from Bergman's Seventh Seal, wherin the knight edge gauges in

506.text: protracted dialogue and the paratracted chess game with the

509.text: Grim Reaper, who didn't seem so terribly grim. The image has

513.text: remained with me ever since. Death as a character appeared in the

518.text: first of my Discworld novels. He's evolved in the series to be one of

523.text: its most pour lar characters, implacable, because that's his job.

525.text: He nevertheless appears to have a sneaking regard and compassion for

532.text: a race of creatures which are, to him, as efef ral as mayflies, but

535.text: which nevertheless spend their brief lives making rules for the

541.text: universe and counting the stars. He is, in short, a kindly death,

545.text: cleaning up the mess that this life leaves and opening the gate to the

549.text: next one. Indeed in some religions he is an Angel.

556.text: People have writ ton me about him from convents, ecclesiastical

559.text: palaces, funeral parlours and not least hospices. The letters I've

562.text: had from people around the world have sometimes made me give up

568.text: writing for the day and take a long walk. It's touching and possibly

572.text: worrying that people will write with some difficulty a six-page

576.text: letter to an author they've never met and include in it sentiments

579.text: that I very much doubt they'd share with their doctor. I've no clear

583.text: recollection of the death of my grandparents, but my paternal

587.text: grandfather died in the ambulance on the way to hospital, after just

593.text: having cooked and eaten his own dinner at the age of 96. It turned

598.text: out when we found his birth certificate that he was really 94.

603.text: But he was proud of being 96, so I hope that no celestial being was

608.text: kind enough to disillusion him. He felt very odd, got a neighbour to

613.text: ring the doctor and stepped tidily into the ambulance and out of the

617.text: worldment He -- world. He died on the way to hospital. A good death,

620.text: if ever there was one. Except that according to my father, he did

624.text: complain to the ambulance men that he hadn't had time to finish his

631.text: I'm not at all sure about the truth of this, because my father had a

635.text: finely tuned sense of humour, which he was good enough to bequeathe to

640.text: me, presumably to make up for the weak bladder, the short stature and

643.text: maem pattern baldness which regrettably came with the package.

2006.text: schedule with the help of a friendly doctor was quite usual.

2012.text: There's every reason to believe that the medical profession

2016.text: considered that part of its duty, to help the stricken patient on

2020.text: their way. Does that still apply? It would seem so. Did The Vic torns

2029.text: fear death? -- did the Victorians fear death? Most men don't fear

2033.text: death, they fear those things, the knife, the shipwreck, the illness,

2037.text: the bomb, which precede by microseconds if you're lucky and

2040.text: many years if you're not, the moment of death. This brings us

2045.text: into the whole care or killing argument. The Care Not Killing

2051.text: Alliance as they phrase it assures us that no-one need consider a

2055.text: voluntary death of any sort since care is always available. This is

2060.text: questionable. Medicine is keeping more and more people alive, all

2065.text: requiring more and more care. Alzheimer's and other demen Shaz

2069.text: place a huge care burden on the country. A burden, which falls

2074.text: initially on the next of kin, who may even be elderly. Indeed they

2079.text: may be in need of care themselves. The number is climbing as the baby

2084.text: boomers get older. In addition, the percentage of cases of dementia

2088.text: amongst the population is also growing. We then have to consider

2092.text: the quality of whatever care there may be, not just for dementia, but

2096.text: for all long-term conditions. I won't go into the horror stories,

2101.text: this isn't the place. And maybe I should leave the field open to Sir

2105.text: Michael Parkinson, who as the Government's dignity ambassador

2111.text: describes incidents that are, and I quote "Absolutely barmy and cruel

2114.text: beyond belief. And care homes as little more than waiting rooms for

2122.text: death." It appears that care is a lottery. There are those of us who

2126.text: don't wish to be cared for, who don't want to spend their time in

2130.text: anyone's waiting room, to have the right not to do what you're told by

2136.text: a nurse, not to obey the doctor. A right in my case, to demand here

2141.text: and now the power of attorney over the fate of the Terry Pratchett

2146.text: that at some future date I will become. People exercise themselves

2151.text: when they wonder what their nearest and dearest would really want. Well

2160.text: my nearest and dearest know and now, so do you. A major objection

2163.text: frequently flourished by opponents to assisted dying is that elderly

2168.text: people might be illegally persuaded into asking for assisted death.

2173.text: Could be. But the Journal of Medical Ethics reported in 2007

2178.text: that there was no evidence of the abuse of vulnerable patients in

2183.text: Oregon, where assisted dying is currently legal. I don't see why

2188.text: things should be any different here. I'm sure nobody considers dying

2192.text: flippantly. The idea that people would persuade themselves to die

2197.text: just because some hypothetical Acme one stop death shop has opened down

2203.text: the road is fantastical. But I can easily enadvicage that a person

2208.text: elderly or otherwise weighed down with medical problems and

2211.text: understandably fearful of the future and dreading what is

2217.text: hopefully called care may consider The Vic torn-style death, gently

2221.text: assisted by a medical professional at home. That might be a more

2226.text: dignified way to go. Last year the Government finally published

2230.text: guidelines on dealing with assisted death. They didn't appear to

2235.text: satisfy anybody. It seems that those wishing to assist a friend or

2240.text: relative to die would have to meet quite a large of criteria in order

2245.text: to escape the chance of prosecution for murder. We should be thankful

2248.text: that some possibility that they might not be prosecuted is in

2252.text: theory, possible. But as laid out, the best anyone could do is keep

2259.text: within the rules and hope for the best. That's why I and others have

2264.text: suggested some kind of strictly non-aggressive tribunal that would

2267.text: establish the facts of the case well before the assisted death

2272.text: takes place. This might make some people, including me a little

2275.text: uneasy, as it suggests the Government has the power to tell

2280.text: you whether you can live or die. But that said, the Government

2283.text: cannot side step the responsibility to ensure the protection of the

2289.text: vulnerable and we must respect that. It grieves me that those against

2293.text: assisted death seem to assume, as a matter of course, that those of us

2297.text: who support it have not thought long and hard about this very issue

2301.text: and know that it's of fundamental importance. It is in fact, at the

2307.text: soul and centre of my argument. The members of the tribunal would be

2313.text: acting for the good of society as well as that of the applicant,

2318.text: horrible word, and ensure that they're of sound and informed mind.

2322.text: Firm in their purpose, sufferinging from a life-threatening and

2328.text: incurable disease and not under the influence of a third party. It

2331.text: would need wiser heads than mine, though heaven knows that they

2336.text: should be easy enough to find to determine how such tribunals are

2340.text: constituted. But I would suggest there should be a lawyer, one with

2348.text: expertise in din afteric family affairs who has become good at

2353.text: recognising what somebody really needs and if there is outside

2357.text: pressure. And a medical expert dealing with the complexities of

2362.text: serious, long-term illnesses. Those opposing assisted death say the

2366.text: vulnerable must be protected, as if that would not have occurred to

2369.text: anyone else. As a matter of fact, there is no evidence, and evidence

2374.text: has been sought, that anywhere in the world, where assisted dying is

2378.text: practiced, the sick or elderly are being cajoled into assisted death

2382.text: by relatives. I see no reason to believe why that would be the case

2386.text: here. Doctors tell me that to the contrary, family members more often

2393.text: beg them to keep granny alive, even when granny is indeed by all

2397.text: medical standards at end of her natural life. Importantly, the

2400.text: tribunal would also serve to prevent, as much as humanly

2407.text: possible, any abuses. I would also suggest that all those on the

2412.text: tribunal are over 45 years old, by which time they may have acquired

2417.text: the rare gift of wisdom. Because wisdom and compassion should in

2422.text: this tribunal stand side by side with the law. The tribunal would

2427.text: also have to be a check on those seeking death for reasons that

2431.text: reasonable people may consider trivial or transient distress. I

2435.text: dare say that quite a few people have contemplated death for reason

2440.text: that's much later seem to them to be quite minor. If we are to live

2445.text: in a world where a socially acceptable early death can be

2450.text: allowed, it must be allowed as a result of careful consideration.

2458.text: Let us consider me as a test case. As I've said, I would like to die

2462.text: peacefully, with Thomas Tallis on my iPod, before the disease takes

2466.text: me over. And I hope that will not be for quite some time to come.

2471.text: Because if I knew that I could die at any time I wanted, then suddenly

2476.text: every day would be as precious as £1 million. If I knew that I could

2482.text: die, I would live. My life, my death, and my choice.

2501.text: There has been no evidence in those areas where assisted dying is

2506.text: currently practiced that it leads to any kind of slippery slope. It

2509.text: seems to be an item of faith among those opposed to assisted dying

2513.text: that it will open the door to abused all the way up to the

2519.text: culling of the elderly sick. This is a nightmare and only a nightmare.

2523.text: This cannot be envisaged in any democracy unless we find ourselves

2528.text: under a tyranny. That is to say, a tyranny that is far more aggressive

2532.text: than the mild one currently operated by the health and safety

2542.text: Frankly, that objection is a bogey man. It's been suggested that

2545.text: people wouldn't trust their doctor if they knew that they had the

2550.text: power to kill them. Why should this be? A doctor has a lot to lose by

2554.text: killing a patient. Indeed it seems to me, that asking a medical

2558.text: practitioner, who is fully aware of your situation, to bring your life

2566.text: it an end, is placing the jut most trust in them. The saying thou

2574.text: shalt not kill, but need not strive efficiently to keep alive, given

2577.text: that it was made up by Arthur Hugh Clough who was in a similar

2581.text: profession to me that is not surprising. Since the birth of

2588.text: medicine, doctors have understood its meaning. They have striven. In

2592.text: the past two centuries we have improved the length of our lives

2596.text: and quality of said lives to the point where we feel somewhat uneasy

2601.text: if anyone dies as early as the biblical age of 70. There comes a

2607.text: time when technology outpaces sense, when we believe a blip is confused

2614.text: with life and the humanity unRavels into a state of mere existence.

2617.text: Observation, conversation and careful deduction leads me to

2621.text: believe that the majority of doctors who support the right-to-

2626.text: die are those who are most closely involved day to day with patients.

2630.text: While support appears to tail off as you reach the heights where

2633.text: politics and medicine merge. It would be interesting to speculate

2638.text: how many doctors would come out, were it not for the baleful glare

2644.text: of the BMA. Anyone who has any long-term friendships, aKuwaitances

2650.text: or professional dealings within the medical profession, laet loan knows

2654.text: the social history -- history of medicine, know that's down the ages

2659.text: it has seen it as part of their duty for those without skill to

2663.text: depart in peace. I can recall the Meta forz used, helping them over

2667.text: the step, showing them the way, helping them find the door.,

2672.text: pointing them to heaven. But never, ever, killing them because in their

2678.text: minds they were not killing. And in their minds they were right. In

2682.text: fact I've not found any reputable information from those places where

2689.text: assisted death is allowed that shows any Dell tierious effect on

2693.text: the community. I do not expect or assume that every GP or hospital

2696.text: practitioner would be prepared to assist death by arrangement. Even

2702.text: in the face of overwhelming medical evidence. That is their choice.

2706.text: Choice is very important in this matter. But there will be some,

2711.text: probably older, probably wiedser, who will understand -- wiser, who

2715.text: will understand. It seems sensible to me that we should look to the

2717.text: medical profession that over the centuries has helped us to live

2722.text: longer and healthier lives, to help us die peacefully among our loved

2729.text: ones in our own home, without a long stay in God's waiting room.

2733.text: And finally, there is the God argument, which I think these days

2737.text: appears to be subassumed into the concern for the innocent that may

2742.text: suffer if assisted dying was allowed. The problem with the God

2746.text: argument is that it only works if you believe in God, more

2753.text: specifically Jehovah, which I do not. Spinoza, Darwin and Marek

2758.text: Saganowski found in my imagination -- Sagan has found in my

2763.text: imagination places which God has not. I am a humanist I would rather

2767.text: believe we are a rising ape not a falling Angel. Nevertheless I have

2771.text: a sneaking regard for the Church of England and those I disagree with.

2776.text: We should always debate ideas that appear to strike at the centre of

2782.text: our humanity, ideas and proposals should be tested. I believe that

2786.text: consensual assisted death for those who ask for it is quite hard to

2790.text: oppose, especially by those who have some compassion. But we do

2795.text: need in this world people to remind us that we are all human. And that

2801.text: humanity is precious. It's that much heralded thing, the quality of

2806.text: life, that's important. How you live your life, what you get out of it,

2812.text: what you put into it and what you leave behind after it.

2815.text: We should aim for a good and rich life well lived and at the end of it

2823.text: in the comfort of our own home in the company of the those who love us

2827.text: have a death worth dying for.

2831.text: Ladies and gentlement Sir Terry Pratchett.
